Specific neurons and neurotransmitters such as norepinephrine, trigger a 
defensive state when we feel that our thoughts have to be protected from 
the influence of others.

If we are then confronted with differences in opinion, the chemicals that 
are released in the brain are the same ones that try to ensure our survival 
in dangerous situations.

In this defensive state, the more primitive part of the brain interferes 
with rational thinking and the limbic system can knock out most of our 
working memory, phisically causing “narrow-mindedness”. No matter how 
valuable an idea is, the brain has trouble processing it when it is in such 
a state. ~ Athene﻿

The concept that our evolution went like "fish, amphibian, reptile, mammal, 
ape" is really antiquated and simplified well beyond accuracy. Especially 
when it's visualized with *modern* versions of those clades.

Yes, we evolved from fish; that's pretty much universally agreed on. Of 
course even here we are not talking about modern fish. We are talking about 
Cambrian fish, which were in many aspects quite different from modern ones. 
However, even Cambrian fish are unambiguously classified as "fish", so it's 
pretty much accurate to say that we did, indeed, evolve from "fish".

However, after that it becomes more complicated than that overly simplistic 
"classical" lineage. We did not evolve from *modern* reptiles, that's for 
certain. It is, to my knowledge, not completely universally agreed whether 
the common ancestor to all modern reptiles and mammals should itself be 
classified as a full-fledged reptile, or whether it should be classified as 
a "proto-reptile" and "proto-mammal" that has some primordial qualities of 
both. It most probably *resembled* a modern reptile more than it resembled 
a modern mammal, but cladistical classification is not done solely on the 
basis of superficial resemblance.

It is, perhaps, as equally wrong to say "we evolved from reptiles" as it is 
to say "we evolved from monkeys". Rather, it's more correct to say "monkeys 
and us evolved from a common ancestor species", and it would also likely to 
be more correct to say that "reptiles and us evolved from a common ancestor 
species". It's of course then a question of how you classify that ancestor 
species. (The common ancestor to all humans and apes is, currently, 
classified as an ape, which makes us apes. With monkeys it becomes fuzzier, 
because they are much more separated in the evolutionary tree from us. 
Currently we are not classified as monkeys because that ancestral species 
is not classified as such. Rather, monkeys evolved *from* that species.)

And by the way, "lizard" and "reptile" are not synonyms. "Lizard" is a 
suborder of reptiles. Not all reptiles are lizards. And we certainly are 
not lizards, even if we classified our common ancestor as a reptile. 
Lizards are actually quite far away in the evolutionary tree from us.

As for David Icke, you are just interpreting the ramblings of a lunatic, 
picking-and-choosing tidbits here and there (and ignoring the rest) to suit 
whichever theory. And no, the current scientific consensus is most 
certainly not that the universe is a hologram. *New Scientist* is pretty 
much a tabloid of science, not an actual peer-reviewed scientific journal. 
It seeks to excite the imaginations of their readers, rather than just 
presenting the cold boring facts. It contains lots of speculative articles 
(which might not be *wrong* per se, but contain only that: Scientific 
speculation. One could perhaps even call it speculative fiction, ie. 
sci-fi.)﻿

What lies beyond our 4 dimensions?
When I was a child, I used to visit the Japanese Tea Garden in San 
Francisco. I would spend hours fascinated by the carp, who lived in a very 
shallow pond just inches beneath the lily pads, just beneath my fingers, 
totally oblivious to the universe above them.
I would ask myself a question only a child could ask: what would it be like 
to be a carp? What a strange world it would be! I imagined that the pond 
would be an entire universe, one that is two-dimensional in space. The carp 
would only be able to swim forwards and backwards, and left and right. But 
I imagined that the concept of “up”, beyond the lily pads, would be totally 
alien to them. Any carp scientist daring to talk about “hyperspace”, i.e. 
the third dimension “above” the pond, would immediately be labelled a 
crank. I wondered what would happen if I could reach down and grab a carp 
scientist and lift it up into hyperspace. I thought what a wondrous story 
the scientist would tell the others! The carp would babble on about 
unbelievable new laws of physics: beings who could move without fins. 
Beings who could breathe without gills. Beings who could emit sounds 
without bubbles. I then wondered: how would a carp scientist know about our 
existence? One day it rained, and I saw the rain drops forming gentle 
ripples on the surface of the pond.

+Michael Woodworth Well, biologists don't really use the term 
"deevolution," because evolution is just change; it doesn't really have a 
direction.  I take your point, though.  On the one hand, powering our 
magnificent brains requires a disproportionately large amount of energy, so 
if we really weren't using them anymore, it's likely that they would evolve 
into "economy models" over time.  In fact, they may have already started.

I think there are a few reasons why outright atrophy or reptilian reversion 
isn't likely to happen, however.  First, even though many of us spend hours 
every day watching TV, and act as though we're allergic to critical 
thought, we still generally use the creative and analytical parts of our 
neocorteces throughout the day.  If you compare the thinking that we tend 
to do today with the thinking that, say, a pre-industrial English serf or 
French peasant did; I think you might find that our intellects are far more 
developed and heavily used.

Second, our bodies are not well suited to competition in the natural 
world.  The reptilian brain is mostly responsible for involuntary urges; to 
eat, to sleep, to have sex, and for an addict, to gamble or do drugs.  It 
really wouldn't be that useful on its own.  If you take away our ability to 
use tools and outwit predators/prey, I think we would soon go extinct; 
victims to the ravages of apex predators, parasitic microbes, hunger and 
the elements.

Third, our slovenly, gluttonous, dimwitted "first world" existence is not 
sustainable for the period of time required to change the gene pool of our 
entire population.  Even the smallest change would almost certainly take 
thousands of years, and we'll be lucky if this flaming nose dive we call a 
civilization will even make it to the next century.  As a side note, if you 
haven't heard about Sir John Glubb's book, "The Fate of Empires and Search 
for Survival," you should check it out.  He postulates a model that every 
great empire seems to progress through, and by his model, the American 
empire is in its decadent decline.  It's pretty interesting stuff, 
especially if you find world history to be personally worthwhile.

Speaking of history, did you know that our brains have shrunk by about 10% 
in the last 5000 years?  Scientists aren't sure why this is, although they 
do have some variably supported hypotheses.  Our bodies have gotten a bit 
smaller, which actually means that our brains don't need to be as big (look 
up encephalization quotient, or EQ).  When we domesticate animals, they 
lose brain size compared to their wild relatives; it could be that we've 
just tamed ourselves.  Some scientists think that our brains are becoming 
more efficient, so we can have the same or greater brain power with smaller 
brains.  Other scientists say that we're just getting dumber.

Thank you so much for being open to other people's perspectives.  If people 
like you were the rule, rather than the exception, I think the world would 
be a much better place.  Cheers.

Thanks +Noah Lucent, that makes a lot of sense and, in hindsight, seems 
obvious now. Alternatively, what are the possibilities of devolution due to 
modern living conditions? Neocortex atrophy of some kind? Could our brains 
revert to a primal 'reptilian' one?

We did not "evolve quicker" than any other species.  Our brains went 
through a period of rapid development, while other species' feet, or necks, 
or digestive systems, or toxicity, or immune systems experienced periods of 
rapid development.  Having a complex brain is not an indicator of how much 
change an evolutionary line has underwent.  Biological evolution is not a 
linear progression from prokaryote to Albert Einstein.  Evolution is often 
"circular."  For instance, there have been horse relatives that looked like 
rhinos, and rhino relatives that looked like giraffes.  Organisms simply 
evolve in adaptation to their constantly changing circumstances, and our 
ancestors circumstances were such that allowed the rapid development of 
complex brains.

We come from the same ancestors. In the past, certain ancestors of ours 
adapted and evolved because of certain ecological/environmental changes 
that forced them to change or die out. This didn't happen to every species 
of fish or lizard; and for some fish and lizards, they evolved into better 
suited fish and lizards to their new environment. Some went on to evolve 
fins that could support walking across short distances of land between 
water sources. Some species couldn't adapt and died out. Some, like the 
lung fish, evolved to be able to breathe without gills. 
 Bottom line being that if you aren't threatened with extinction or extreme 
environmental changes, there is little reason for change. Not every fish 
and lizard is forced to evolve. Thats why we still have fishes and lizards 
and monkeys.

Poverty is the principal cause of hunger. The causes of poverty include 
poor people's lack of resources, an extremely unequal income distribution 
in the world and within specific countries, conflict, and hunger itself. As 
of 2008 (2005 statistics), the World Bank has estimated that there were an 
estimated 1,345 million poor people in developing countries who live on 
$1.25 a day or less.1 This compares to the later FAO estimate of 1.02 
billion undernourished people.  Extreme poverty remains an alarming problem 
in the world’s developing regions, despite some progress that reduced 
"dollar-now $1.25- a day" poverty from (an estimated) 1900 million people 
in 1981, a reduction of 29 percent over the period. Progress in poverty 
reduction has been concentrated in Asia, and especially, East Asia, with 
the major improvement occurring in China. In Sub-Saharan Africa, the number 
of people in extreme poverty has increased.  The statement that 'poverty is 
the principal cause of hunger'  is, though correct, unsatisfying.  Why then 
are (so many) people poor?

According to the most recent estimate that Hunger Notes could find, 
malnutrition, as measured by stunting, affects 32.5 percent of children in 
developing countries--one of three (de Onis 2000). Geographically, more 
than 70 percent of malnourished children live in Asia, 26 percent in Africa 
and 4 percent in Latin America and the Caribbean. In many cases, their 
plight began even before birth with a malnourished mother. Under-nutrition 
among pregnant women in developing countries leads to 1 out of 6 infants 
born with low birth weight. This is not only a risk factor for neonatal 
deaths, but also causes learning disabilities, mental, retardation, poor 
health, blindness and premature death.

The world produces enough food to feed everyone. World agriculture produces 
17 percent more calories per person today than it did 30 years ago, despite 
a 70 percent population increase. This is enough to provide everyone in the 
world with at least 2,720 kilocalories (kcal) per person per day  according 
to the most recent estimate that we could find (FAO 2002, p.9).  The 
principal problem is that many people in the world do not have sufficient 
land to grow, or income to purchase, enough food.

Actually, bones don't normally last very long at all.  They contain 
minerals that are relatively rare in most ecosystems, and many organisms 
see them as a tasty treat.  The only bones that we can use to study the 
archaic world are not actually bones at all, but fossils.  A fossil is a 
long dead organism or part of an organism whose chemical constituents have 
been mostly replaced by minerals, turning it into a rock.  It is only a 
VERY tiny fraction of living things that ever recieve this geological 
distinction.  Also, when fossils are made, it's nearly always because they 
are buried in the ground.  That makes them pretty tough to find.  
Furthermore, even though we've only been looking for a relatively short 
time, there is already a fossil record that quite reasonably describes an 
evolutionary "progression" from ancient african apes, through many species 
of australopithecines, to at least a dozen stages of hominids, right down 
to our current specie, homo sapiens.  This fossil record is continually 
being filled in, as discoveries are regularly being made.

All those shape shifting videos showing world leaders and such experiencing 
changes in their eyed, ears, or face, are actually a function of digital 
photography. The actual digital  impulses from the pixels are processed in 
a computer, and the resultant file is compressed into a useful video format 
that can be saved on a mass storage device. All this digital processing 
causes distortions to be introduced into the final image, which are mostly 
unnoticeable when watching a video. However, if you examine individual 
frames they can be seen. Compression is most likely the main culprit, 
because each frame is not a single frame as in old celluloid films, but a 
composite of two or more frames blended together.﻿

It's known as pseudo science. Take a comment by a professor somewhere, 
distort it, add a few 'supportive' ideas from elsewhere and it becomes a 
scientific fact. The medulla oblongata is the oldest (in evolutionary 
terms) part of the brain and the most primitive and really forms part of 
the brain stem; it is a complex crossroads of nerve tissue. It is here that 
the "involuntary" processes of the body - the reflex centres which control 
breathing, cardiac function, swallowing vomiting and facial movement are 
originated. With emotive words like "primitive" appended to it, it is not 
difficult to see why erroneous or even misleading statements can be made. 
Yes the medulla (for short) is present in most species. This fact does not 
support the Lizard theory beyond the tenet that brains, to a point shared 
an evolutionary path, hence the expression 'reptile' applied to the medulla 
oblongata but that is as far as we can take the story.﻿

All those posts showing prominent people apparently shape shifting, where 
their pupils change to slits, or scales appear on their faces, are in fact 
inbuilt malfunctions of digital media. All digital video is compressed to 
make the video files much smaller so that it can be streamed. This is 
basically just changing the pixels of everything in a frame that has moved, 
while retaining the unchanging pixels as they are, thus reducing greatly 
the amount of information that has to be transmitted. However this can 
produce distortions which most viewers would not even notice, especially as 
our brains expect continuity. These conspiracy theorists sift through 
videos frame by frame until they find one with distotions in it, then 
present it as proof of shape shifting. Dumb.﻿

Your three dimensional reality has an equivalent two dimensional 
representation. This is what your scientists are saying. They aren't saying 
that your reality is a hologram. They are saying that it is possible to 
flatten your 3D world to a 2D space. Think of a matrix where each column is 
for (x,y) and each row is for the z coordinate. That is what is going on 
here. You have a function like f(x,y,z) = (row,column). It is possible to 
map the nth dimension to the (n-1)th dimension via a conversion formula. 
You have to account for things like virtual space which is part of the nth 
dimension but not the (n-1)th dimension. Here n is an element from the set 
of natural numbers. For f(x,y,z), the virtual space is one of the 
coordinate axes of 3D space.﻿

Comets elliptically orbit the sun and are thought to be as old as the sun.

theory", you will find many websites that give very good arguments for 
evolution. Again I will mention that we understand evolution not only from 
observations on fossils / current life, but we also have a very good 
biological understanding of the mechanism behind it.

And as TragicShow argued, not all theories have to be true all the time. 
Even very well accepted laws of physics aren't true all the time. For 
example, conservation of mass is a very important physical concept, but 
Einstein proved it does not hold if the object moves very fast. Many 
mechanical properties and fluid dynamics are very well accepted and hold on 
macro scale, but fail once you examine them on a atomic or molecular level. 
This doesn't invalidate the law, it just shows you shouldn't apply this law 
on a micro scale.

You will find cases where evolution did unexpected things. However, for 
every flaw in the theory you will find a thousand other proofs.

And yes, it will be difficult to see any evolution take place in your 
lifetime. Although you do not believe the earth is old, we are fairly 
certain it is about 4.5 billion years old. And with fairly certain, I mean 
there are loads of evidence to support it.

+Jesus Defender No you didn't. You just talked about some of the reasons 
why you believe evolution is wrong, which +Remon Damen already covered. 
Furthermore, you highlighted your ignorance of science in the very first 
paragraph of your biased rant against evolution. Of course evolution is not 
a law. Just because something is a theory, that doesn't mean it could be 
wrong. Theories will never become laws. For example, the Earth revolves 
around the sun. I think that's something we can agree is a fact, however, 
heliocentrism is only a theory. That is because heliocentrism is not a law 
of the universe. There is no law of heliocentrism, only the theory of 
heliocentrism. Laws are also known to be incorrect in certain circumstances 
as well. So the lesson of today is: Just because it's a theory, that 
doesn't mean it could be wrong, and just because it's a law, that doesn't 
mean it always has to be right.

are plenty of examples of helpful mutations in organisms. If you paid 
attention in your high school biology class, you would know this. Do you 
know why new antibiotics have to be developed for the same strand of 
bacteria? They mutate to form a resistance to the old one. You are likely 
thinking of drastic mutations such as an extra arm or something. In that 
case, no, they are generally not beneficial. However, smaller scale 
beneficial mutations can be found in virtually every human being. As an 
example, I was born without wisdom teeth, and I have extra cusps on my 
molars which allow me to chew more efficiently. There are no negative side 
effects from this, so it isn't neutral and it certainly is not deleterious.
